steps.title: Build an emergency fund
steps.description: Set aside a buffer of at least $22,500 to handle unexpected expenses. Aim for 3–6 months of living expenses if possible.

steps.title: Contribute to retirement plan
steps.description: If your employer offers a 401(k) or similar plan with a match, contribute at least enough to get the full match. It's essentially free money.

steps.title: Build an emergency fund
steps.description: Set aside a buffer of at least $12,500 to handle unexpected expenses. Aim for 3–6 months of living expenses if possible.

steps.title: Pay down high‑interest debt
steps.description: Focus on paying off any debt with an interest rate above 7% before investing heavily elsewhere. Consider the debt avalanche method: list balances by interest rate and tackle the highest first.

steps.title: Contribute to retirement plan
steps.description: If your employer offers a 401(k) or similar plan with a match, contribute at least enough to get the full match. It's essentially free money.

steps.title: Create a starter budget
steps.description: Develop a simple monthly budget to track expenses and avoid accumulating debt. Use tools like the 50/30/20 rule to allocate needs, wants and savings.

steps.title: Build credit responsibly
steps.description: Open a low‑fee credit card (if you don't have one) and pay the balance in full each month. A strong credit history will help with future loans and housing.

steps.title: Purchase term life insurance
steps.description: If you have dependents, ensure they are protected by obtaining affordable term life insurance. Choose coverage that can replace your income for 10–15 years.
